C ANGE IN DATE
OF FIRST COTILLION
An announcement of the
Cotillon Board states that the
date of the First Cdtillon has
been changed to Friday, December 7th. The affair will be
held at Lehmann's Hall from
10 till 2. Refreshments will lie
served and as an innovation—
gold and silver 'favours presented to all. In- addition,
there will be a figure led by
some prominent senior.
-Although the admission
price, $3.50 a couple or
stag, is slightly higher than in
the pap, this affair will be on a higher. level than Previous
cotillons, and. should be one
of the outstanding social
events of the collegiate llileason.,

ASSEMBLY VOTES TO HAVE PARADE
ON EVE OF MARYLAND .GAME
In response to the enthusiasm
displayed in its favor at Assembly
a parade will be held before the
Maryland game for the first time in
the history of the University. All
the Freshmen.are to be at the Barn
-at 7 o'clock Wednesday evening. At
that time the class roll will be
called. All men neither*Present 'nor
excused will be brought before the
Student Council with-the probable
penalty of two days' suspension
from the University. All those unable to attend must fill out a written application and leave it with
Donald Hiss, President of the Student Council, before Wednesday.
Flares and dynamite powder will be
given out promiscuously to those
who attend.

the girls' dormitories. As the young
ladies will ottly have a one day holiday at Thanksgiving it is expected
that there will be a large number
of them on hand for the occasion.
The Herbert Co. is making signs
for the parade such as "Hopkins
was `Hopkins when Maryland was a
farmyard," "Man the lifeboats! The
Old Lineis are going down," "We'll
have terrapin soup to-night," "Our
Scotch line will not give," and many
others. Floats used in the St. John's
parade and many new ones will be
seen. At the City Hall Plaza Maryland will be hanged 'and burnt in
effigy as the astral act of an elaborate ceremony.

SCHIEBEL DID NOT
RUN IN NEW YORK
Herman Schiebel, captain
of the track team, who was to
have gone, to ,New York to
run in the Intercollegiate
Championships, did not do so,
because it was feared that,
with the Maryland Cross
Country meet so near at hand,
his participation might be
_ prejudicial to his performance
tomorrow. The New • York
meet was held yesterday.
Schiebel's work is regarded as
very important to -the Hotkins team.

HOPKINS-MARYLAND
CLASSIC THURSDAY
Black and Gold Is Favorite in
This Year's Setto
JAYS FIGHTING MAD
Hopkins' Team Out to Avenge
St. John's Defeat
Turkey Day in the Stadium will
see Hopkins and Maryland once
more engaged in the struggle for
athletic supremacy when the twd
sets of grid warriors once more take
the field. Maryland is the heavy
favorite, but then, who can remember when Maryland was anything
but that? The Old Line victory
over Yale seems to point to storms
ahead for the Blue clad team, and
after last Saturday's game the horizon does look a bit clouded.
However, there is one thing which
will be in the Jays' favor, that is
that Maryland never seems to be
able to get the idea: out of their
heads that Hopkins will be "easy."
For the past few years the Hopkins
team has gone into the game the
under-dog and for the past few
years it has emerged from the contest with about as much of the opponent's hide as it has lost. It is
odd but Jay teams always seem to
play better against Maryland when
they are not conceded half a
chance than when things are supposed to be on even terms or better.
The Terrapin players just can't help
being cocky; after the past Saturday
the Jaymen just won't be; that will,
help to make things a bit more even.

mand the bus stopped to (J,.
charge them as absorbed in sophistry they moved,toward the University gates.
While the tired laborer slept in
•his seat the poet next,to him was
overcome by his muse and taking the agglomeration of mist and
dirt, people and trees, sidewalks
and fountains he liberated some
of the lyric by pounding against
•
the walls of his heart.
"The speck of dust has wings,
And so have I.
The very sidewalks sings
Of joys untold
And so do I.
And all the other things
In life grow bold
And so do I.
The world's a world of moons for
me—
And the dust is made of stars.
The streets are paths of jubilees
And the moonbeams silver bars.
About me cOme and go
• - The crowds of quiet men_
Who seeming calm and slow
- As llent shadows of a glen„
Esoteric charm and beauty know..
And he scratched away on an
old play program, his improved
notebook while the 'notions of the

H
C ANGE IN DATE
OF FIRST COTILLION
An announcement of the
Cotillon Board states that the
date of the First Cdtillon has
been changed to Friday, December 7th. The affair will be
held at Lehmann's Hall from
10 till 2. Refreshments will lie
served and as an innovation—
gold and silver 'favours presented to all. In- addition,
there will be a figure led by
some prominent senior.
-Although the admission
price, $3.50 a couple or
stag, is slightly higher than in
the pap, this affair will be on a higher. level than Previous
cotillons, and. should be one
of the outstanding social
events of the collegiate llileason.,

ASSEMBLY VOTES TO HAVE PARADE
ON EVE OF MARYLAND .GAME
In response to the enthusiasm
displayed in its favor at Assembly
a parade will be held before the
Maryland game for the first time in
the history of the University. All
the Freshmen.are to be at the Barn
-at 7 o'clock Wednesday evening. At
that time the class roll will be
called. All men neither*Present 'nor
excused will be brought before the
Student Council with-the probable
penalty of two days' suspension
from the University. All those unable to attend must fill out a written application and leave it with
Donald Hiss, President of the Student Council, before Wednesday.
Flares and dynamite powder will be
given out promiscuously to those
who attend.

the girls' dormitories. As the young
ladies will ottly have a one day holiday at Thanksgiving it is expected
that there will be a large number
of them on hand for the occasion.
The Herbert Co. is making signs
for the parade such as "Hopkins
was `Hopkins when Maryland was a
farmyard," "Man the lifeboats! The
Old Lineis are going down," "We'll
have terrapin soup to-night," "Our
Scotch line will not give," and many
others. Floats used in the St. John's
parade and many new ones will be
seen. At the City Hall Plaza Maryland will be hanged 'and burnt in
effigy as the astral act of an elaborate ceremony.

SCHIEBEL DID NOT
RUN IN NEW YORK
Herman Schiebel, captain
of the track team, who was to
have gone, to ,New York to
run in the Intercollegiate
Championships, did not do so,
because it was feared that,
with the Maryland Cross
Country meet so near at hand,
his participation might be
_ prejudicial to his performance
tomorrow. The New • York
meet was held yesterday.
Schiebel's work is regarded as
very important to -the Hotkins team.

HOPKINS-MARYLAND
CLASSIC THURSDAY
Black and Gold Is Favorite in
This Year's Setto
JAYS FIGHTING MAD
Hopkins' Team Out to Avenge
St. John's Defeat
Turkey Day in the Stadium will
see Hopkins and Maryland once
more engaged in the struggle for
athletic supremacy when the twd
sets of grid warriors once more take
the field. Maryland is the heavy
favorite, but then, who can remember when Maryland was anything
but that? The Old Line victory
over Yale seems to point to storms
ahead for the Blue clad team, and
after last Saturday's game the horizon does look a bit clouded.
However, there is one thing which
will be in the Jays' favor, that is
that Maryland never seems to be
able to get the idea: out of their
heads that Hopkins will be "easy."
For the past few years the Hopkins
team has gone into the game the
under-dog and for the past few
years it has emerged from the contest with about as much of the opponent's hide as it has lost. It is
odd but Jay teams always seem to
play better against Maryland when
they are not conceded half a
chance than when things are supposed to be on even terms or better.
The Terrapin players just can't help
being cocky; after the past Saturday
the Jaymen just won't be; that will,
help to make things a bit more even.
